abstracts.cdata!:
The implementation of the Douala
            Infrastructure Project envisages serious environmental
            adversity, namely resulting from construction works,
            aggravating traffic circulation, which is already hampered
            by frequent flooding, and in turn leads to accelerated
            roadways degradation, and, includes as well, the risk of
            soil erosion, in addition to potential disease increases,
            such as typhoid, and viral hepatitis. Measures to mitigate
            adversity follow. Traffic signaling, and safety measures
            will limit circulation, and speed in the proximity of
            construction areas, while depots, and/or sanitary
            installations will be located at safe distances from water
            flows (at least five hundred meters apart). Hydraulic
            systems along roads construction should prevent the frequent
            flooding from nearby river flows, and, effluents will be
            appropriately channeled. Landscaping, and re-vegetation
            practices would control soil erosion, and air pollution, in
            addition to slope terracing to contain erosion. Working
            schedules will be limited to daytime hours, in order to
            mitigate noise disturbances. Public awareness campaigns will
            address the public health risks involved, aiming at disease
            prevention, and control. Since construction will involve
            mainly urban areas, no social nor resettlement issues are
            envisaged, neither any adversity on archaeological sites.
